Community Hub
Age of Fear 2: The Chaos Lord
Age of Fear 2: The Chaos Lord is the award-winning indie fantasy turn-based strategy. The game features a novel battle system, two campaigns with solid fantasy stories, and very flexible multiplayer and skirmish modes.
User reviews: Positive (38 reviews) - 81% of the 38 user reviews for this game are positive.
Release Date: Mar 27, 2015

Recent updates View all (21)

October 29

Update released (v2.6.1)!

Hi all,


This is major update as we are releasing restrictions to upgradable skills - till now every skill was available at any time if unit had enough experience.

With this update skills are limited to unit's level - for example, Archmages will get Time Shift spell only at Elite level.

Also, for Mac OS X and Linux users - Java has been bundled (1.8.0_60), therefore it's not necessary to install it separately any longer.

All feedback is welcome!


Take care,
Les

Age of Fear: The Undead King available on Steam!

Reviews

“Age of Fear succeeds because of its combat: using units to protect fragile allies, incorporating hex-based mechanics without the geometric restriction. The result is some satisfying strategy, choosing which units to move and carefully keeping your army intact and away from open avenues for the enemy. (...) Speaking of the AI, I found it to be quite competent: it takes advantage of openings to attack frail units, retreats vulnerable ranged units, and uses special skills intelligently. (...) Age of Fear delivers some nice strategic gaming recommended for fans of turn-based fantasy titles!”
6/8 – Out of Eight

“Age of Fear 2: The Chaos Lord (...) deliberately and unapologetically invokes the spirit of early 90s strategy games, before real-time strategy became the fashion and reflexes became more important than tactics. I reviewed the PC version, but it's available for Linux and Mac as well. Age of Fear 2: The Chaos Lord is a decent entry in a very underserved genre. It's not perfect, but it is fun, playable, and challenging, and it shows every sign of rapidly improving itself.”
4/5 – PCWorld

About This Game

Age of Fear 2: The Chaos Lord is the sequel of the award-winning fantasy turn-based strategy Age of Fear: The Undead King. The game features a novel battle system, two campaigns with solid fantasy stories, and very flexible multiplayer and skirmish modes.

The story takes place in an untamed fantasy land, where four forces: H

Venceremos
799 products in account
27 reviews
Recommended
13.7 hrs on record
Posted: August 11
The Good
The best thing about the game is, (without abusing summoners) it's challenging enough without making you sick. In fact, with the right tactics you can beat a battle with 0 casualty. Luck factors do exist, but can be solved with a few SLs. I've done both campaigns I've not lost one single unit yet (except for Goblin Kamikazes and summoned creatures).

The Bad
The game is amazing aside from a few minor grammatical mistakes that sometimes annoy me, even though my English is really orcish. Me no anglais!
Battles are well designed and **CAN BE** challenging...
If you choose not to use summoners (devil campaign). After I've had Remove Chaos Magic perk for all my four summoners, all I need to do is keep summoning friends... no, fiends.
Orc campaign is comparatively harder, but clever use of Goblin Catchers can easily turn the table.
Some creatures seem rather useless. I mean, who would use Giant Spider when Kara gets Berserker for free?
Campaigns are relatively short. In less than 14 hours I beat both campaigns with every possible choice.

The Ugly
Graphics? But for a game of such fun, who needs next-gen graphics?

All in all, your game is on the right path. I think. -- not Raphael
No, it's not only that, it's amazing. It worth every penny of it and the dev is very responsive and friendly. And I am already looking forward to AOF3 (and AOF1 discount as well).

Gorbash
137 products in account
5 reviews
Recommended
22.0 hrs on record
Posted: August 6
A hidden gem for any TBS fan.

Two campaigns of ca. 15 battles each interspaced with some of the most amusing storyline (very much tongue in check, in a refreshing manner) will definitely return your moneys worth.

In the beginning your troops will die and any single one you manage to rescue into the next stage is cherished. The longer they live, the better they become. Towards the end they are nigh unstoppable, but that is when you can increase the difficulty to even the odds (I did).

I might start a second playthrough, now that I'm aware of what I can expect and select my troops accordingly. I selected at least one of every type to find out what upgrades are available on the first round (spiders and bats for example are very situational and need careful consideration, it might be better to include an allpurpose unit like a mage or succubus instead etc.)

What I like is that the two campaigns favour a different playstyle....As orcs you have a very solid melee wall and try to snipe the opposing frontline with hypnotize to turn their own troops against them....As succubus you flood the enemy with summons and snipe with fireballs, not caring if it hits your own summons.

Loved both ways:)

Oh and a small tip, hidden stashes are automatically detected, as soon as one of your troops can reach the spot...so to find anything (not every map has secrets), walk a fast runner all around the map before leaving the battle(use of t-key was very helpful here).

Random
719 products in account
11 reviews
Recommended
8.6 hrs on record
Posted: October 11
A good little turn based strategy rpg featuring two different campaigns. The first, featuring you as a demon is easier. The second, where you play as an orc, is a bit tougher.

Pros:
Combats play quickly.
Fair variety of units.
Hilarious writing in the story sections.
Choose your own adventure style quest.
A fair amount of customization options for your army, what you bring, and how you level them up.
If you take the time to read it, there are help screens that will walk you through all the mechanics of the game.
Lots of options to craft the experience you want.

Cons:
The graphics are not great.
17 pages of different licenses was a little weird. One of the licenses for Quara something was "use at your own risk". Um.... ok.
Scrolling the screen to move around is very clunky sometimes, and I found I kept needing to switch camera depth.

All in all a worthwhile experience for the price. I recommend this to anyone that likes this style of game.

All Is One
157 products in account
1 review
Recommended
14.8 hrs on record
Posted: June 24
Okay, where to begin. All in all, this is a great game, I absolutely love it. The combat and leveling systems are interesting and can certainly provide you with some challenges and difficult decisions.
The simple graphics really doesn't take away from this game, rather the opposite, it helps set the mood.
If like me, you grew up plaing games like Master of Magic, One must fall, Tank Wars etc, then you'll know that HD graphics does NOT a-good-game-make.

The story is quite funny, they've written an old-shcool adventure, with everything that goes with that.
Yes, it's obvious in the writing/spelling that english isn't the creators' first language. So if you're a complete grammar-nazi then that may bother you, if not... Then it probably wont be a problem for you.

tl:dr:
All in all a great little game that's definetely worth your time and money =)

Posted: November 4
Awesome TBS gem - really is alot of fun. Interesting units, movement/combat mechanics seem are different in a good way (everything has a radius on the them and that dictates how your units move and fight with opponents). Love the hellish theme. Graphics could be improved, but the underpinnings of a fun game are there so no great loss. Recommended.
